Award.AwardTitle: Planning IUCRC Baylor College of Medicine: Center to Stream Healthcare In Place (C2SHIP)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Various aspects of economic burden of the United States are associated with an aging population, of whom 70% will need some kind of long-term care. C2SHIP (Center to Stream Heathcare In Place) will unite the best minds in academic medicine with leaders in the biomedical industry to research and develop intelligent monitoring and intervening wearable technologies, and in particular will be focused on enabling and promoting aging in place, personalized medicine, and smart management of chronic and non-communicable disease through telecommunication, data mining, and comprehensive feedback. The thrust of our research will be on the aging patient's central role and responsibility in enabling an optimized healthcare ecosystem. This award supports planning for the formation of this Industry-University Cooperative Research Center (IUCRC).

Our trans-disciplinary research will pursue research and development in reconfigurable designs and system integration centered on the aging/health "in place" concept: establishment of an environment or mobile hub for patient-in-need within his/her own location facilitated by the streaming of data to medical professionals at remote locations in real time through the Internet of Things. This represents a crucial first step toward characterizing abnormalities in environment and activity. Moreover, C2SHIP will focus on the mitigation of physiological, environmental, and psychological changes for real time management and intervention as well as infuse new in place technologies into relevant user communities and residences.

C2SHIP will investigate techniques and mechanisms that can facilitate real time interventions for a number of chronic diseases. The Center will not only advance the science of physiology, aging and pediatric medicine but also accelerate both knowledge and intellectual property transfer between academia and industry through our collaborative partnerships. This will allow for the rapid development of new in place technologies that can potentially transform health care delivery, reduce health care costs related to care of chronic disease and preventable readmissions, and, moreover, improve outcomes and quality of life for aging and chronically-ill patients.

POR.DRECONTENT:
More than 10,000 Americans-a-day reach Medicare age, some of whom will develop multiple chronic conditions and account for a large share of Medicare spending. All of these factors continue to overwhelm unchanging healthcare delivery systems. In response, many healthcare providers are re-engineering their pathways of care for patients with chronic disease to promote alternatives to repeated hospitalizations. Because management of chronic conditions requires lifestyle and daily behavior change, a greater emphasis must be placed on the patient’s central role and responsibility in healthcare. Focusing on the patient in this way constitutes an important shift in current clinical practice. At present, systems relegate the patient to the role of passive recipient of care, missing the opportunity to leverage what he or she can do to promote personal health (in-place care). Healthcare for chronic conditions must be re-oriented around the patient and caregivers.

However, to date there is no I-UCRC center in U.S. to accelerate development of ‘in-place’ technology to facilitate management of chronic disease in-place as an alternative to repeated hospitalization. To address this gap, we teamed up with the University of Arizona and proposed ‘Center to Stream HealthCare In place’ or ‘C2SHIP’. C2SHIP led by Dr. Janet Roveda at the University of Arizona (UA) and Dr. Bijan Najafi at the Baylor College of Medicine (BCM) will be committed to research & development in three pillars  of contemporary human health and development: growing-up-in-place, healthy aging-in-place, and precision environmental health. The “in-place” concept emphasizes using reconfigurable designs and system integration ideas to establish an environment or mobile hub for a person-in-need at his/her own location, and stream the data to professionals at remote locations in real time through Internet of Things. The main emphasis of this Center will be on the patient’s central role and responsibility in enabling an optimized healthcare ecosystem.

To plan the C2SHIP, we have performed and successfully achieved the following milestones:

1)      BootCamp Workshop: We attended a one day Boot Camp workshop organized by NSF in January 2018 to gain skills to design strategies for building membership through customer discovery and corporate engagement.

2)      Building mission statement and value proposition documents: In this phase with collaboration of key investigators from both universities, we fine-tuned our mission statement and value propositions. We had also regular teleconference with VentureWell Consultants as well as NSF program director to successfully achieve the milestone for the customer discovery phase and critically evaluate our center value proposition.

3)      Interviewing potential members: We have successfully interviewed 31 industries including interviewing leaders (e.g. CEO. CTO, CFO, program director, etct) from top 100 fortunes companies including Medline, Stryker, Medtronic, IBM, Phillips, Texas Instruments, etc.

4)      Finalizing Business Model Canvas: Through the process of customer interview process and with support of consultants from VentureWell, we have finalized our ‘Business model Canvas’ for our C2SHIP center.

5)      Site visits and engaging industrial members: Through our customer interview process, we identified potential industrial members who are willing to support the mission of our center and agree to sign our center agreement. Through this process, we organized site visit for 8 potential industrial members and organized tour to our facilities as well as meeting with key faculties of our institutions.

6)      Discovery additional academic sites: Our efforts in academicals partner discovery led to engagement of 4 new academic members including U of Missouri, U of Southern California, U of Texas in Austin, and Caltech.

7)      Organizing planning workshop: We successfully organized our first planning workshop in Houston including 70+ attendees from 7 academic institutes and 20+ potential industrial members attended in two days workshops (6 and 7 November, 2018). 11 podium project presentations and 29 project posters were presented. All project presentations were graded by the invited industrial members.

8)      Executing agreement and collecting formal signatures from industrial members: We are happy to report that 4 industrial members including WeHealth by Servier, Medline, Circulation Concepts, and MedoPad signed our agreements.

9)      Submission of the Phase I grant: with collaboration of our academic sites we have worked to finalize the Phase I proposal and is anticipated to submit with April Cycle.

10)   Data Management: We have also developed plans to perform data managements among different sites, industrial members and hospitals and clinics. Shared resources include data storage,  Artificial Intelligence/Machine Learning training data sets, trained deep learning network, frameworks to facilitate new sensor data and diagnosis results comparison, and NIST required cybersecurity framework for  biomedical sensors and data.

11)   Education: We also developed plans for students, postdoc, and research associate trainings, as well as trainings for existing caregivers. New resources such as ZOOM and others are being used as large scale remote meetings and webinars. We also leverage other resources such as NSF internship programs, State funding resources to facilitate cross-sties project developments.
